exploration_path.sentence_content: I began with a broad affordability scan to see which boroughs sit in the lower rent band across London.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: rent distribution by borough (bar), rent band selector, highlight below-/near-median group

exploration_path.sentence_content: Since the client cares about schools and public services, I pivoted to a schools-access lens while keeping that affordability band in view.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: schools per 10k residents (heatmap), rent-band filter pill, shortlist toggle

exploration_path.sentence_content: Within the affordable band, I shortlisted boroughs in the top quartile for school access.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: quartile overlay on schools heatmap, shortlist panel (Candidate Set A)

exploration_path.sentence_content: I added public libraries as a services proxy and intersected that with the schools shortlist.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: libraries per 10k (bar), intersection badge on candidates

exploration_path.sentence_content: To avoid mistaking cheap for good, I normalized by rent-to-income and pruned the list to those with manageable burden.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: rent-to-income ratio bars, threshold slider, prune action on shortlist

exploration_path.sentence_content: Because cultural fit matters, I checked diversity patterns for the remaining boroughs.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: diversity index (ethnicity entropy / country-of-birth spread), candidate highlights

exploration_path.sentence_content: As a sanity check on everyday access, I looked at restaurants per 10k without drifting into nightlife.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: restaurants per 10k (bar), affordability band shading on bars

exploration_path.sentence_content: I verified consistency across the key signals—schools, libraries, rent burden, and diversity—using small multiples per candidate.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: small-multiple tiles per candidate (schools, libraries, ratio, diversity) with pass/fail ticks

exploration_path.sentence_content: With a stable set, I drafted a preliminary recommendation framing these boroughs as strong balances of schools and services within budget.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: narrative composer prefilled with evidence-linked snippets from the last three views

exploration_path.sentence_content: Before finalizing, I ran a reflection pass and softened any borderline claims that didn’t hold across multiple views.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: timeline of prior sentences with evidence badges and quick-jump to their charts

exploration_path.sentence_content: Conclusion A (schools-first): recommend the top two to three boroughs that consistently pair strong school access and public libraries with acceptable rent-to-income and solid diversity.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: final summary card with pinned candidates and linked charts

exploration_path.sentence_content: In parallel, I explored an alternative hypothesis starting from cultural fit—surfacing high-diversity boroughs first.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: diversity index leaderboard, rent-band filter applied

exploration_path.sentence_content: I intersected that high-diversity set with the same affordability band to maintain budget alignment.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: set intersection view (diversity ∧ affordability), candidate chip list

exploration_path.sentence_content: Next, I overlaid schools and libraries to test whether diverse areas also provide good access to public services.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: dual-metric overlay (schools and libraries) on the intersected set

exploration_path.sentence_content: Where diversity and services aligned within budget, I formed a candidate set; where they didn’t, I noted a diversity–services trade-off for the summary.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: candidate set panel with alignment flags; trade-off notes

exploration_path.sentence_content: Conclusion B (cultural-fit-first): recommend boroughs where community diversity coexists with acceptable rent and accessible schools/libraries, noting any trade-offs explicitly.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: summary composer scoped to cultural-fit-first branch

exploration_path.sentence_content: I also tested a different method: a weighted score combining schools, libraries, diversity, and a penalty for rent burden, with presets for school-heavy or services-balanced renters.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: weight sliders (w_school, w_library, w_diversity, w_ratio), preset buttons

exploration_path.sentence_content: I ranked boroughs by the composite score and used a waterfall chart to show how each component contributed.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: ranked list by score, waterfall per candidate

exploration_path.sentence_content: To assess stability, I ran a sensitivity analysis by varying weights ±15% to see if the same boroughs remained on top.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: tornado/sensitivity plot, rank-change ribbons across weight ranges

exploration_path.sentence_content: I then compared the scoring picks against the earlier rule-based shortlist to identify consistent versus brittle recommendations.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: Venn/comparison view (score-top vs rule-shortlist), stability badges

exploration_path.sentence_content: I marked ‘robust’ candidates that appear across multiple weightings and also in the rule-based set.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: robust-candidate tags, filter to robust only

exploration_path.sentence_content: Conclusion C (method synthesis): recommend robust candidates that persist under weighting changes and match the earlier rule-based rationale.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: synthesis card combining robust tags with evidence links

exploration_path.sentence_content: From the schools-first shortlist, I overlaid diversity and found at least one borough strong on schools and libraries but relatively low on diversity.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: overlay—schools/libraries strength vs diversity index, conflict flag on the outlier

exploration_path.sentence_content: For the schools-strong but diversity-low case, I lowered confidence for renters who prioritize cultural fit.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: confidence dial tied to renter persona (cultural-fit priority)

exploration_path.sentence_content: Conversely, for the diversity-strong but services-modest case, I checked proximity to adjacent higher-service boroughs within the same rent band as a mitigation.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: adjacency map, travel-time cards to nearby higher-service boroughs

exploration_path.sentence_content: I documented the split as conditional guidance: keep the schools-strong option for academics-first renters; nudge diversity-first renters toward the mitigated alternative.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: branch notes panel with ‘if/then’ recommendations and evidence links

exploration_path.sentence_content: Conclusion D (conflict-aware): present two paths—schools-first versus diversity-first—with explicit trade-offs and who benefits from each.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: dual-path summary cards with target personas

exploration_path.sentence_content: I ran a quick quality check on the library and schools data to ensure coverage and freshness were sufficient for weighting.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: data-quality panel—coverage %, last update, variance by borough

exploration_path.sentence_content: Where coverage was thin, I flagged the claim and routed back to the rent-burden normalization to avoid over-weighting a weak signal.
exploration_path.system_shows: Dashboard: inline warning on sentences using thin metrics; one-click jump back to ratio pruning view

data_story.data_story_sentence: Focusing on rental affordability, an initial borough-level scan identified a below- and near-median rent band to frame the search space.
Within this affordability band, we pivoted to a schooling lens to align with the client’s priorities on education and public services.
Filtering for boroughs in the top quartile of schools within the affordability band produced a focused candidate set for families.
Intersecting that set with public library density refined candidates to places where learning and civic services co-locate.
Normalizing by rent-to-income confirmed these candidates maintain a manageable housing burden rather than appearing merely ‘cheap for a reason.’
Adding a cultural-fit lens via diversity indices highlighted boroughs where community variety aligns with affordability and service access.
A light amenity check using restaurants per capita indicated everyday access without over-indexing on nightlife.
Consistency checks across schools, libraries, rent burden, and diversity—via small-multiple tiles—supported a stable shortlist.
Under the schools-first synthesis, recommended boroughs are those that jointly meet education and service access while staying within an acceptable rent burden and diverse community context.

As an alternative hypothesis, beginning from cultural diversity and then intersecting with affordability, schools, and libraries yielded a complementary shortlist for renters prioritizing community fit.

A methodological cross-check using a weighted multi-criteria score—stress-tested via sensitivity analysis—identified robust candidates that persist across parameter changes and align with the rule-based shortlist.

Where evidence conflicted—strong schools and services but lower diversity, or the reverse—the narrative branches into conditional guidance: schools-first options for academics-focused renters, diversity-first options where community fit leads.
Quality controls on data coverage and freshness were applied; thin or uneven signals were flagged and routed back to rent-burden normalization to avoid overweighting weak evidence.
